column49: and there I found everything just as I had been told. I went up to the tree beneath which stood the fountain
column50: and filling the silver bowl with water
column51: emptied it on the marble slab. Thereupon the thunder came
column52: louder by far than I had expected to hear it
column53: and after the thunder came the shower
column54: but heavier by far than I had expected to feel it
column55: for
column56: of a truth I tell thee
column57: Kai
column58: not one of those hailstones would be stopped by skin or by flesh till it had reached the bone. I turned my horse’s flank towards the shower
column59: and
column60: bending over his neck
column61: held my shield so that it might cover his head and my own. When the hail had passed
column62: I looked on the tree and not a single leaf was left on it
column63: and the sky was blue and the sun shining
column64: while on the branches were perched birds of very kind
column65: who sang a song sweeter than any that has come to my ears
column66: either before or since.‘“O knight
column67: what has brought thee hither? What evil have I done to thee
column68: that thou shouldest do so much to me
column69: for in all my lands neither man nor beast that met that shower has escaped alive.” Then from the valley appeared the knight on the black horse
column70: grasping the lance with the black pennon. Straightway we charged each other
column71: and though I fought my best
column72: he soon overcame me
column73: and I was thrown to the ground
column74: while the knight seized the bridle of my horse
column75: and rode away with it
column76: leaving me where I was
column77: without even despoiling me of my armour.

column1: ‘Sadly did I go down the hill again
column2: and when I reached the glade where the black man was
column3: I confess to thee
column4: Kai
column5: it was a marvel that I did not melt into a liquid pool
column6: so great was my shame. That night I slept at the castle where I had been before
column7: and I was bathed and feasted
column8: and none asked me how I had fared. The next morning when I arose I found a bay horse saddled for me
column9: and
column10: girdling on my armour
column11: I returned to my own court. The horse is still in the stable
column12: and I would not part with it for any in Britain.‘But of a truth
column13: Kai
column14: no man ever confessed an adventure so much to his own dishonour
column15: and strange indeed it seems that none other man have I ever met that knew of the black man
column16: and the knight and the shower.’With the first rays of the sun he set forth
column17: and travelled through deserts and over mountains and across rivers
column18: and all befell him which had befallen Kynon
column19: till he stood under the leafless tree listening to the song of the birds. Then he heard the voice
column20: and turning to look found the knight galloping to meet him. Fiercely they fought till their lances were broken
column21: and then they drew their swords
column22: and a blow from Owen cut through the knight’s helmet
column23: and pierced his skull.Feeling himself wounded unto death the knight fled
column24: and Owen pursued him till they came to a splendid castle. Here the knight dashed across the bridge that spanned the moat
column25: and entered the gate
column26: but as soon as he was safe inside
column27: the drawbridge was pulled up and caught Owen’s horse in the middle
column28: so that half of him was inside and half out
column29: and Owen could not dismount and knew not what to do.While he was in this sore plight a little door in the castle gate opened
column30: and he could see a street facing him
column31: with tall houses. Then a maiden with curling hair of gold looked through the little door and bade Owen open the gate.‘Well
column32: ’ said she
column33: ‘I will do my best to release thee if thou wilt do as I tell thee. Take this ring and put it on with the stone inside thy hand
column34: and close thy fingers tight
column35: for as long as thou dost conceal it
column36: it will conceal thee. When the men inside have held counsel together
column37: they will come to fetch thee to thy death
column38: and they will be much grieved not to find thee. I will stand on the horse block yonder and thou canst see me though I cannot see thee. Therefore draw near and place thy hand on my shoulder and follow me wheresoever I go.’Then Owen went to the maiden and placed his hand on her shoulder
column39: and she guided him to a large room
column40: painted all over with rich colours
column41: and adorned with images of gold. Here she gave him meat and drink
column42: and water to wash with and garments to wear
column43: and he lay down upon a soft bed
column44: with scarlet and fur to cover him
column45: and slept gladly.‘What is it?’ he asked
column46: and she answered that the knight who owned the castle was dead
column47: and they were bearing his body to the church. Never had Owen beheld such vast crowds
column48: and following the dead knight was the most beautiful lady in the world
column49: whose cry was louder than the shout of the men
column50: or the braying of the trumpets. And Owen looked on her and loved her.‘I will tell thee
column51: ’ answered Luned. ‘Unless thou canst defend the fountain all will be lost
column52: and none can defend the fountain except a knight of Arthur’s court. There will I go to seek him
column53: and woe betide me if I return without a warrior that can guard the fountain
column54: as well as he who kept it before.’So Luned set out
column55: riding on a white palfrey
column56: on pretence of journeying to King Arthur’s court
column57: but instead of doing that she hid herself for as many days as it would have taken her to go and come
column58: and then she left her hiding-place
column59: and went into the countess.Therefore the next day at noon Owen put on his coat of mail
column60: and over it he wore a splendid mantle
column61: while on his feet were leather shoes fastened with clasps of gold. And he followed Luned to the chamber of her mistress.At her words the chief men of the city withdrew into one corner and took counsel together
column62: and after a while the leader came forward and said that they had decided that it was best
column63: for the peace and safety of all
column64: that she should choose a husband for herself. Thereupon Owen was summoned to her presence
column65: and he accepted with joy the hand that she offered him
column66: and they were married forthwith
column67: and the men of the earldom did him homage.

column1: From that day Owen defended the fountain as the earl before him had done
column2: and every knight that came by was overthrown by him
column3: and his ransom divided among his barons. In this way three years passed
column4: and no man in the world was more beloved than Owen.‘Oh
column5: Gwalchmai
column6: I am grieved concerning Owen
column7: whom I have lost these three years
column8: and if a fourth year passes without him I can live no longer. And sure am I that the tale told by Kynon the son of Clydno caused me to lose him. I will go myself with the men of my household to avenge him if he is dead
column9: to free him if he is in prison
column10: to bring him back if he is alive.’Then Arthur and three thousand men of his household set out in quest of Owen
column11: and took Kynon for their guide. When Arthur reached the castle
column12: the youths were shooting in the same place
column13: and the same yellow man was standing by
column14: and as soon as he beheld Arthur he greeted him and invited him in
column15: and they entered together. So vast was the castle that the king’s three thousand men were of no more account than if they had been twenty.Immediately all happened as before; the thunder and the shower of hail which killed many of Arthur’s men; the song of the birds and the appearance of the black knight. And Kai met him and fought him
column16: and was overthrown by him. Then the knight rode away
column17: and Arthur and his men encamped where they stood.In the morning Kai again asked leave to meet the knight and to try to overcome him
column18: which Arthur granted. But once more he was unhorsed
column19: and the black knight’s lance broke his helmet and pierced the skin even to the bone
column20: and humbled in spirit he returned to the camp.‘Well
column21: fight then
column22: ’ answered Arthur
column23: and Gwalchmai threw a robe over himself and his horse
column24: so that none knew him. All that day they fought
column25: and neither was able to throw the other
column26: and so it was on the next day. On the third day the combat was so fierce that they fell both to the ground at once
column27: and fought on their feet
column28: and at last the black knight gave his foe such a blow on his head that his helmet fell from his face.‘My lord
column29: ’ he said
column30: ‘during the three years that I have been absent from thee I have been preparing a banquet for thee
column31: knowing full well that thou wouldst come to seek me. Tarry with me
column32: therefore
column33: for a while
column34: thou and thy men.’So they rode to the castle of the countess of the fountain
column35: and spent three months in resting and feasting. And when it was time for them to depart Arthur besought the countess that she would allow Owen to go with him to Britain for the space of three months. With a sore heart she granted permission
column36: and so content was Owen to be once more with his old companions that three years instead of three months passed away like a dream.One day Owen sat at meat in the castle of Caerleon upon Usk
column37: when a damsel on a bay horse entered the hall
column38: and riding straight up to the place where Owen sat she stooped and drew the ring from off his hand.At her words Owen remembered all that he had forgotten
column39: and sorrowful and ashamed he went to his own chamber and made ready to depart. At the dawn he set out
column40: but he did not go back to the castle
column41: for his heart was heavy
column42: but he wandered far into wild places till his body was weak and thin
column43: and his hair was long. The wild beasts were his friends
column44: and he slept by their side
column45: but in the end he longed to see the face of a man again
column46: and he came down into a valley and fell asleep by a lake in the lands of a widowed countess.Now it was the time when the countess took her walk
column47: attended by her maidens
column48: and when they saw a man lying by the lake they shrank back in terror
column49: for he lay so still that they thought he was dead. But when they had overcome their fright
column50: they drew near him
column51: and touched him
column52: and saw that there was life in him. Then the countess hastened to the castle
column53: and brought from it a flask full of precious ointment and gave it to one of her maidens.‘Take that horse which is grazing yonder
column54: ’ she said
column55: ‘and a suit of men’s garments
column56: and place them near the man
column57: and pour some of this ointment near his heart. If there is any life in him that will bring it back. But if he moves
column58: hide thyself in the bushes near by
column59: and see what he does.’

column1: The damsel took the flask and did her mistress’ bidding. Soon the man began to move his arms
column2: and then rose slowly to his feet. Creeping forward step by step he took the garments from off the saddle and put them on him
column3: and painfully he mounted the horse. When he was seated the damsel came forth and greeted him
column4: and glad was he when he saw her and inquired what castle that was before him.‘It belongs to a widowed countess
column5: ’ answered the maiden. ‘Her husband left her two earldoms
column6: but it is all that remains of her broad lands
column7: for they have been torn from her by a young earl
column8: because she would not marry him.’‘That is a pity
column9: ’ replied Owen
column10: but he said no more
column11: for he was too weak to talk much. Then the maiden guided him to the castle
column12: and kindled a fire
column13: and brought him food. And there he stayed and was tended for three months
column14: till he was handsomer than ever he was.‘Nay
column15: but I will give them to him
column16: and such a horse and armour and weapons as he has never had yet
column17: though I know not what use they will be to him. Yet mayhap it will save them from falling into the hands of my enemies.’‘Await me
column18: ’ said Owen
column19: ‘at the gate of the castle
column20: and he cried a challenge to the earl
column21: who came to meet him. Hard did they fight
column22: but Owen overthrew his enemy and drove him in front to the castle gate and into the hall.After that he departed
column23: and went into the deserts
column24: and as he was passing through a wood he heard a loud yelling. Pushing aside the bushes he beheld a lion standing on a great mound
column25: and by it a rock. Near the rock was a lion seeking to reach the mound
column26: and each time he moved out darted a serpent from the rock to prevent him. Then Owen unsheathed his sword
column27: and cut off the serpent’s head and went on his way
column28: and the lion followed and played about him
column29: as if he had been a greyhound. And much more useful was he than a greyhound
column30: for in the evening he brought large logs in his mouth to kindle a fire
column31: and killed a fat buck for dinner.Owen made his fire and skinned the buck
column32: and put some of it to roast
column33: and gave the rest to the lion for supper. While he was waiting for the meat to cook he heard a sound of deep sighing close to him
column34: and he said:‘I am held captive in this cave on account of the knight who married the countess and left her
column35: for the pages spoke ill of him
column36: and because I told them that no man living was his equal they dragged me here and said I should die unless he should come to deliver me by a certain day
column37: and that is no further than the day after to-morrow. His name is Owen the son of Urien
column38: but I have none to send to tell him of my danger
column39: or of a surety he would deliver me.’Owen held his peace
column40: but gave the maiden some of the meat
column41: and bade her be of good cheer. Then
column42: followed by the lion
column43: he set out for a great castle on the other side of the plain
column44: and men came and took his horse and placed it in a manger
column45: and the lion went after and lay down on the straw. Hospitable and kind were all within the castle
column46: but so full of sorrow that it might have been thought death was upon them. At length
column47: when they had eaten and drunk
column48: Owen prayed the earl to tell him the reason of their grief.‘Yesterday
column49: ’ answered the earl
column50: ‘my two sons were seized
column51: while thy were hunting
column52: by a monster who dwells on those mountains yonder
column53: and he vows that he will not let them go unless I give him my daughter to wife.’Early next morning the dwellers in the castle were awakened by a great clamour
column54: and they found that the giant had arrived with the two young men. Swiftly Owen put on his armour and went forth to meet the giant
column55: and the lion followed at his heels. And when the great beast beheld the hard blows which the giant dealt his master he flew at his throat
column56: and much trouble had the monster in beating him off.

column1: ‘Truly
column2: ’ said the giant
column3: ‘I should find no difficulty in fighting thee
column4: if it were not for that lion.’ When he heard that Owen felt shame that he could not overcome the giant with his own sword
column5: so he took the lion and shut him up in one of the towers of the castle
column6: and returned to the fight. But from the sound of the blows the lion knew that the combat was going ill for Owen
column7: so he climbed up till he reached the top of the tower
column8: where there was a door on to the roof
column9: and from the tower he sprang on to the walls
column10: and from the walls to the ground. Then with a loud roar he leaped upon the giant
column11: who fell dead under the blow of his paw.Now the gloom of the castle was turned into rejoicing
column12: and the earl begged Owen to stay with him till he could make him a feast
column13: but the knight said he had other work to do
column14: and rode back to the place where he had left Luned
column15: and the lion followed at his heels. When he came there he saw a great fire kindled
column16: and two youths leading out the maiden to cast her upon the pile.‘She boasted that no man in the world was equal to Owen
column17: ’ said they
column18: ‘and we shut her in a cave
column19: and agreed that none should deliver her but Owen himself
column20: and that if he did not come by a certain day she should die. And now the time has past and there is no sign of him.’Then Owen shut up the lion in the cave where the maiden had been in prison
column21: and blocked up the front with stones. But the fight with the giant had sorely tried him
column22: and the youths fought well
column23: and pressed him harder than before. And when the lion saw that he gave a loud roar
column24: and burst through the stones
column25: and sprang upon the youths and slew them. And so Luned was delivered at the last. In the old land of Brittany
column26: once called Cornwall
column27: there lived a woman named Barbaik Bourhis
column28: who spent all her days in looking after her farm with the help of her niece Tephany. Early and late the two might be seen in the fields or in the dairy
column29: milking cows
column30: making butter
column31: feeding fowls; working hard themselves and taking care that others worked too. Perhaps it might have been better for Barbaik if she had left herself a little time to rest and to think about other things
column32: for soon she grew to love money for its own sake
column33: and only gave herself and Tephany the food and clothes they absolutely needed. And as for poor people she positively hated them
column34: and declared that such lazy creatures had no business in the world.Well
column35: this being the sort of person Barbaik was
column36: it is easy to guess at her anger when one day she found Tephany talking outside the cowhouse to young Denis
column37: who was nothing more than a day labourer from the village of Plover. Seizing her niece by the arm
column38: she pulled her sharply away
column39: exclaiming:‘What does fortune matter?’ repeated Barbaik
column40: in a shocked voice. ‘Is it possible that you are really so foolish as to despise money? If this is what you learn from Denis
column41: I forbid you to speak to him
column42: and I will have him turned out of the farm if he dares to show his face here again. Now go and wash the clothes and spread them out to dry.’‘She is harder than these rocks
column43: ’ said the girl to herself
column44: ‘yes
column45: a thousand times harder. For the rain at least can at last wear away the stone
column46: but you might cry for ever
column47: and she would never care. Talking to Denis is the only pleasure I have
column48: and if I am not to see him I may as well enter a convent.’Thinking these thoughts she reached the bank
column49: and began to unfold the large packet of linen that had to be washed. The tap of a stick made her look up
column50: and standing before her she saw a little old woman
column51: whose face was strange to her.‘Those who help others deserve to be helped
column52: ’ she answered; ‘your eyes are still red because that miser Barbaik has forbidden you to speak to the young man from Plover. But cheer up
column53: you are a good girl
column54: and I will give you something that will enable you to see him once every day.’‘Take this long copper pin
column55: ’ she went on
column56: ‘and every time you stick it in your dress Mother Bourhis will be obliged to leave the house in order to go and count her cabbages. As long as the pin is in your dress you will be free
column57: and your aunt will not come back until you have put it in its case again.’ Then
column58: rising
column59: she nodded to Tephany and vanished.

column1: The girl stood where she was
column2: as still as a stone. If it had not been for the pin in her hands she would have thought she was dreaming. But by that token she knew it was no common old woman who had given it to her
column3: but a fairy
column4: wise in telling what would happen in the days to come. Then suddenly Tephany’s eyes fell on the clothes
column5: and to make up for lost time she began to wash them with great vigour.Next evening
column6: at the moment when Denis was accustomed to wait for her in the shadow of the cowhouse
column7: Tephany stuck the pin in her dress
column8: and at the very same instant Barbaik took up her sabots or wooden shoes and went through the orchard and past to the fields
column9: to the plot where the cabbages grew. With a heart as light as her footsteps
column10: the girl ran from the house
column11: and spent her evening happily with Denis. And so it was for many days after that. Then
column12: at last
column13: Tephany began to notice something
column14: and the something made her very sad.At first
column15: Denis seemed to find the hours that they were together fly as quickly as she did
column16: but when he had taught her all the songs he knew
column17: and told her all the plans he had made for growing rich and a great man
column18: he had nothing more to say to her
column19: for he
column20: like a great many other people
column21: was fond of talking himself
column22: but not of listening to any one else. Sometimes
column23: indeed
column24: he never came at all
column25: and the next evening he would tell Tephany that he had been forced to go into the town on business
column26: but though she never reproached him she was not deceived and saw plainly that he no longer cared for her as he used to do.Day by day her heart grew heavier and her cheeks paler
column27: and one evening
column28: when she had waited for him in vain
column29: she put her water-pot on her shoulder and went slowly down to the spring. On the path in front of her stood the fairy who had given her the pin
column30: and as she glanced at Tephany she gave a little mischievous laugh and said:‘He has grown tired of me
column31: ’ answered Tephany in a trembling voice
column32: ‘and he makes excuses to stay away. Ah! granny dear
column33: it is not enough to be able to see him
column34: I must be able to amuse him and to keep him with me. He is so clever
column35: you know. Help me to be clever too.’Blushing with pleasure Tephany went home and stuck the feather into the blue ribbon which girls always wear in that part of the country. In a moment she heard Denis whistling gaily
column36: and as her aunt was safely counting her cabbages
column37: she hurried out to meet him. The young man was struck dumb by her talk. There was nothing that she did not seem to know
column38: and as for songs she not only could sing those from every part of Brittany
column39: but could compose them herself. Was this really the quiet girl who had been so anxious to learn all he could teach her
column40: or was it somebody else? Perhaps she had gone suddenly mad
column41: and there was an evil spirit inside her. But in any case
column42: night after night he came back
column43: only to find her growing wiser and wiser. Soon the neighbours whispered their surprise among themselves
column44: for Tephany had not been able to resist the pleasure of putting the feather in her hair for some of the people who despised her for her poor clothes
column45: and many were the jokes she made about them. Of course they heard of her jests
column46: and shook their heads saying:It was not long before Denis began to agree with them
column47: and as he always liked to be master wherever he went
column48: he became afraid of Tephany’s sharp tongue
column49: and instead of laughing as before when she made fun of other people he grew red and uncomfortable
column50: thinking that his turn would come next.Tephany’s face fell; she had worked hard all day
column51: and had been counting on a quiet hour with Denis. She did her best to persuade him to remain with her
column52: but he would not listen
column53: and at last she grew angry.‘Fasten this necklace round your neck
column54: and as long as you wear it you will be the most beautiful woman in the world
column55: ’ continued the fairy. With a little shriek of joy Tephany took the necklace
column56: and snapping the clasp ran to the mirror which hung in the corner. Ah
column57: this time she was not afraid of Aziliez or of any other girl
column58: for surely none could be as fair and white as she. And with the sight of her face a thought came to her
column59: and putting on hastily her best dress and her buckled shoes she hurried off to the dance.

column1: ‘I don’t want to be a great lady
column2: I only want to be the wife of Denis
column3: ’ she replied
column4: throwing off his hand and running to the ditch which divided the road from the cornfield
column5: where he hoped to hide. Unluckily the young man guessed what she was doing
column6: and signed to his attendants
column7: who seized her and put her in the coach. The door was banged
column8: and the horses whipped up into a gallop.At the end of an hour they arrived at a splendid castle
column9: and Tephany
column10: who would not move
column11: was lifted out and carried into the hall
column12: while a priest was sent for to perform the marriage ceremony. The young man tried to win a smile from her by telling of all the beautiful things she should have as his wife
column13: but Tephany did not listen to him
column14: and looked about to see if there was any means by which she could escape. It did not seem easy. The three great doors were closely barred
column15: and the one through which she had entered shut with a spring
column16: but her feather was still in her hair
column17: and by its aid she detected a crack in the wooden panelling
column18: through which a streak of light could be dimly seen. Touching the copper pin which fastened her dress
column19: the girl sent every one in the hall to count the cabbages
column20: while she herself passed through the little door
column21: not knowing whither she was going.By this time night had fallen
column22: and Tephany was very tired. Thankfully she found herself at the gate of a convent
column23: and asked if she might stay there till morning. But the portress answered roughly that it was no place for beggars
column24: and bade her begone
column25: so the poor girl dragged herself slowly along the road
column26: till a light and the bark of a dog told her that she was near a farm.In front of the house was a group of people; two or three women and the sons of the farmer. When their mother heard Tephany’s request to be given a bed the good wife’s heart softened
column27: and she was just going to invite her inside
column28: when the young men
column29: whose heads were turned by the girl’s beauty
column30: began to quarrel as to which should do most for her. From words they came to blows
column31: and the women
column32: frightened at the disturbance
column33: pelted Tephany with insulting names. She quickly ran down the nearest path
column34: hoping to escape them in the darkness of the trees
column35: but in an instant she heard their footsteps behind her. Wild with fear her legs trembled under her
column36: when suddenly she bethought herself of her necklace. With a violent effort she burst the clasp and flung it round the neck of a pig which was grunting in a ditch
column37: and as she did so she heard the footsteps cease from pursuing her and run after the pig
column38: for her charm had vanished.On she went
column39: scarcely knowing where she was going
column40: till she found herself
column41: to her surprise and joy
column42: close to her aunt’s house. For several days she felt so tired and unhappy that she could hardly get through her work
column43: and to make matters worse Denis scarcely ever came near her.As the days went on Tephany grew paler and paler
column44: till everybody noticed it except her aunt. The water-pot was almost too heavy for her now
column45: but morning and evening she carried it to the spring
column46: though the effort to lift it to her shoulder was often too much for her.‘How could I have been so foolish
column47: ’ she whispered to herself
column48: when she went down as usual at sunset. ‘It was not freedom to see Denis that I should have asked for
column49: for he was soon weary of me
column50: nor a quick tongue
column51: for he was afraid of it
column52: nor beauty
column53: for that brought me nothing but trouble
column54: but riches which make life easy both for oneself and others. Ah! if I only dared to beg this gift from the fairy
column55: I should be wiser than before and know how to choose better.’‘Be satisfied
column56: ’ said the voice of the old woman
column57: who seemed to be standing unseen at Tephany’s elbow. ‘If you look in your right-hand pocket when you go home you will find a small box. Rub your eyes with the ointment it contains
column58: and you will see that you yourself contain a priceless treasure.’Tephany did not in the least understand what she meant
column59: but ran back to the farm as fast as she could
column60: and began to fumble joyfully in her right-hand pocket. Sure enough
column61: there was the little box with the precious ointment. She was in the act of rubbing her eyes with it when Barbaik Bourhis entered the room. Ever since she had been obliged to leave her work and pass her time
column62: she did not know why
column63: in counting cabbages
column64: everything had gone wrong
column65: and she could not get a labourer to stay with her because of her bad temper. When
column66: therefore
column67: she saw her niece standing quietly before her mirror
column68: Barbaik broke out:

column1: Tephany tried to stammer some excuse
column2: but her aunt was half mad with rage
column3: and a box on the ears was her only answer. At this Tephany
column4: hurt
column5: bewildered and excited
column6: could control herself no longer
column7: and turning away burst into tears. But what was her surprise when she saw that each tear-drop was a round and shining pearl. Barbaik
column8: who also beheld this marvel
column9: uttered a cry of astonishment
column10: and threw herself on her knees to pick them up from the floor.‘Take care not to let any of the neighbours hear of it
column11: Denis
column12: ’ said Barbaik. ‘Of course you shall have your share
column13: but nobody else shall get a single one. Cry on
column14: my dear
column15: cry on

column11: which you see. Look at my wings also--are they not withered stumps? Yet until to-day I have never heard of the man you name. Still
column12: I will guide you to the oldest animal in the world
column13: and the one that has travelled most
column14: the eagle of Gwern Abbey.’ And he flew before them
column15: as fast as his old wings would carry him
column16: till he reached the eagle of Gwern Abbey
column17: but when they inquired of the eagle whether he knew aught of Mabon he shook his head.‘When I first came hither
column18: ’ said the eagle
column19: ‘there was a rock here
column20: and every evening I pecked at the stars from the top of it. Now
column21: behold
column22: it is not even a span high! But only once have I heard of the man you name
column23: and that was when I went in search of food as far as Llyn Llyw. I swooped down upon a salmon
column24: and struck my claws into him
column25: but he drew me down under water till scarcely could I escape him. Then I summoned all my kindred to destroy him
column26: but he made peace with me
column27: and I took fifty fish spears from his back. Unless he may know something of the man whom you seek I cannot tell who may. But I will guide you to the place where he is.’‘As much as I know I will tell thee. With every tide I go up the river
column28: till I reach the walls of Gloucester
column29: and there have I found such wrong as I never found elsewhere. And that you may see that what I say is true let two of you go thither on my shoulders.’ So Kai and Gwrhyr went upon the shoulders of the salmon
column30: and were carried under the walls of the prison
column31: from which proceeded the sound of great weeping.Then they sent a messenger to Arthur to tell him that Mabon was found
column32: and he brought all his warriors to the castle of Gloucester and fell fiercely upon it; while Kai and Bedwyr went on the shoulders of the salmon to the gate of the dungeon
column33: and broke it down and carried away Mabon. And he now being free returned home with Arthur.After this
column34: on a certain day
column35: as Gwythyr was walking across a mountain he heard a grievous cry
column36: and he hastened towards it. In a little valley he saw the heather burning and the fire spreading fast towards the anthill
column37: and all the ants were hurrying to and fro
column38: not knowing whither to go. Gwythyr had pity on them
column39: and put out the fire
column40: and in gratitude the ants brought him the nine bushels of flax seed which Yspaddaden Penkawr required of Kilweh. And many of the other marvels were done likewise by Arthur and his knights
column41: and at last it came to the fight with Trwyth the board
column42: to obtain the comb and the scissors and the razor that lay between his ears. But hard was the boar to catch
column43: and fiercely did he fight when Arthur’s men gave him battle
column44: so that many of them were slain.Up and down the country went Trwyth the boar
column45: and Arthur followed after him
column46: till they came to the Severn sea. There three knights caught his feet unawares and plunged him into the water
column47: while one snatched the razor from him
column48: and another seized the scissors. But before they laid hold of the comb he had shaken them all off
column49: and neither man nor horse nor dog could reach him till he came to Cornwall
column50: whither Arthur had sworn he should not go. Thither Arthur followed after him with his knights
column51: and if it had been hard to win the razor and the scissors
column52: the struggle for the comb was fiercer still
column53: but at length Arthur prevailed
column54: and the boar was driven into the sea. And whether he was drowned or where he went no man knows to this day.
